III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Description qualifications
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was penetrated around the age of 7 or 8 by an unknown
staff member.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/2/2025 and
reported they had no additional information.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/3/2025. Chief Administrator is not aware of the
allegation. CA stated she does not recall Youth A reporting he was
sexually abused during his placement at the facility. The file of
Youth A has been purged due to it being over 7 years since
Youth’s A placement. Youth A was placed at the facility between
9/2014 – 1/2016 and she reported he was placed at the agency a
second time.
Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
6/3/2025. Clinical Director is not aware of the allegation. They
stated they are not aware of Youth A reporting any sexual abuse
allegations during his placement at the facility.
Residential Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/3/2025. Residential Supervisor 1 is not aware of the
allegations. Residential Supervisor 1 stated Youth A never
reported sexual abuse during his placement at the facility that they
are aware of.
Youth A was interviewed via video conference on 6/4/2025.
Youth A stated he was raped in 2014 and 2016 by an African
American male staff member at the facility. Youth A mentioned he
could not recall the name of the staff member but described the
employee to be Staff 1 (later identified to be Staff 1). Staff 1 did
pass away from Covid 19 in 2020 and Youth A learned Staff 1 had
passed away from Facebook. Youth A stated in each rape in 2014
and 2016, Staff 1 took him to his office, pinned him down, tied his
legs with rope or handcuffs, and raped him. He stated there were
2

no cameras or witnesses. Youth A stated Staff 1 did not use
protection. Youth A reported this to staff but does not recall who
he reported this to. He stated this staff he told this to, told him he
was lying.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed over the phone on
6/13/2025. Chief Administrator reported the only African American
male staff who passed away from Covid-19 is Staff 1. Staff 1
passed away from Covid-19 around April 2020. CA reported Staff
1 has been working at the facility since 2005 as the Activities
Coordinator. His job title changed to Health and Safety Director in
2016. CA was his direct supervisor from 2018-2020. CA reported
Staff 1 trained other staff in education, CPI and CPR trainings.
Staff 1 was not a supervisor or director and had little interaction
with the youth. CA stated Staff 1 was loved by everyone, and no
one ever complained about him. He was an amazing person, and
his death was traumatic for everyone at the facility. CA stated she
does not believe the allegation and Staff 1 would never harm a
child.
Clinical Director was interviewed over the phone on
8/18/2025. Clinical Director stated she worked with Staff 1 from
2001 and until his passing in April of 2020. She stated Staff 1 was
the mascot of the facility, and he was a father figure to some of
the boys at the facility. She stated she is shocked by the
allegations made towards Staff 1. She has never seen or heard of
Staff 1 being inappropriate with any youth. Youth A has never
disclosed to her any sexual abuse and she was his therapist from
2014-2016.
Former Staff 2, does not have a phone number listed in his
file.
Former Staff 3, was called on 8/10/2025. Messages were left
and a phone call has not been returned.
Former Therapist, was called on 8/10/2025. Messages were
left and a phone call has not been returned.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Per MiSACWIS, Youth A was placed at the facility from
9/2014 – 1/2016 and again from, 8/2019 – 8/2020.
• Staff 1 personnel file: There are no grievances or
disciplinary actions regarding the allegations.
• There are no incident reports between Staff 1 and Youth A.
• Setting Boundaries Policy:
3

o Employees are prohibited from: Engaging in verbal/sexual
harassment, physical abuse or neglect of persons served
or persons within the person’s served care system,
including person’s served family or friends.
o It is the policy of Christ Child House that employees,
volunteers, or other stakeholders may not participate in
fraud, abuse, waste of resources or other wrongdoing,
whether illegal or unethical. Ethical violations and
legal/unethical wrongdoing shall be reported. Employees
are encouraged to report any suspicion or evidence in the
aforementioned areas to their immediate supervisor,
Executive Director or Associate Director. Christ Child
House shall uphold a “no reprisal” approach for employees
and volunteers in reporting suspected incidents of waste,
fraud, abuse, and other questionable activities and
practices, and/or violations of ethical codes.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews, there is
insufficient evidence to support the allegations of Staff 1 sexually
assaulting Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth B overpowered Youth A, and sexually assaulted him and
anally penetrated Youth A when he was 7 or 8 years old.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/2/2025 and
reported they had no additional information.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/3/2025. Chief Administrator (CA) reported she is not
aware of the allegation and Youth A never reported he was
sexually abused by Youth B. CA stated Youth B is very cognitively
impaired. Youth B’s cognitive functioning is lower than Youth A’s.
Youth B never sexually acted out and there are no incident reports
of Youth B being inappropriate with other youth. The files of Youth
A and Youth B have been purged due to the time frames being
over 7 years since their placement. There is no contact
information on file for Youth B. Youth A was placed at the facility
between 9/2014 – 1/2016 and returned a second time.
4

Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
6/3/2025. Clinical Director reported she is not aware of the
allegation as Youth A never reported any inappropriate
interactions with Youth B. Youth B is extremely low in his cognitive
functioning and therefore, was mostly around adults and not other
youth. Youth B never displayed sexualized behaviors or any had
any reports of sexual concern during his placement at the facility.
Youth A has never disclosed to her any sexual abuse and she
was his therapist from 2014-2016.
Residential Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/3/2025. Residential Supervisor 1 reported he is not
aware of the allegation. Youth A never reported to him being
sexually abused by Youth B. Youth B never displayed any
concerning behavior at the facility.
Youth A was interviewed via video conference on 6/4/2025.
Youth A stated Youth B forced himself onto Youth A when Youth
A was 12 years old. He stated he did tell staff but, he does not
recall which staff and there were no witnesses. Youth A stated
that unknown staff called his mother and told her Youth A had
consensual sex with Youth B. Youth A did state Youth B has
special needs.
The agency did not have any contact information for Youth B.
A MiSACWIS search on 7/7/2025 did not produce any contact
information for Youth B and Youth B is 24 years old.
Therefore, Youth B was unable to be located for an interview.
Former Staff 2, does not have a phone number listed in his
file.
Former Staff 3, was called on 8/10/2025. Messages were left
and a phone call has not been returned.
Former Therapist, was called on 8/10/2025. Messages were
left and a phone call has not been returned.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Per MiSACWIS, Youth A’s mother’s parental rights were
terminated on 5/17/2021 to Youth A. Youth A was placed
at the facility from 9/2014 – 1/2016 and again from, 8/2019
– 8/2020.
• Per MiSACWIS, Youth B was placed from 2/2011 – 8/2016
and placed a second time 9/2016 – 5/2019.
5

• There are no incident reports between Youth A and Youth
B or grievances.
• Supervision and Scheduling Criteria Policy:
o Christ Child House utilizes “Line of Sight” supervision at all
times. Children must be in eyesight of their staff at all
times, outside of personal times (bathroom, inside shower).
In times of crisis we utilize “Suicide Watch” and “Run-a-way
Status” in which that child is to remain in arm’s length of
staff at all times. Within these special crisis time those
children are also to be in pajamas to give them a sense of ,
“I don’t want to run in pajamas”, shoes are taken from them
and all clothing outside of pajama, underwear, and socks
are removed from their rooms until they have been
evaluated and cleared to return to the milieu without high
alerts. Suicide watch children have all items that would
allow for them to hurt themselves removed from their rooms
as well such as plastics that could be sharpened down,
shoelaces, hangers, etc. If a child is on special alerts we
utilize extra staffing if necessary to help ensure his safety.
o Christ Child House also utilizes 1:4 Youth Specialist to child
ration during awake hours and on midnights we utilize 1:10
ratio with bed checks at least every 15 minutes but to be
sporadic in nature. We also have cameras in the upstairs
bedroom hallway to assist with monitoring.
o Employees of Christ Child House are broken down into
Administration/Management, Full-time, and Part-time milieu
staff. Milieu staff (Supervisors/Coordinators/Youth
Specialist) are responsible to ensure that children are
separated by their assigned groups every shift to keep
down incidence of bullying, or any other negative behaviors
that are an outcome of having older and younger boys
together. Each group is put together based on each child’s
individual needs, cognitive development, and any other
special conditions that they may present.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews, there is
insufficient evidence to support Youth B sexually assaulting Youth
A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An unknown staff member broke Youth's A hand (unknown if left
or right), shattered some bones, and informed Youth A that he
needed to state his mother did this. The date of this incident, the
age of Youth A and the intentions of the staff member are
unknown.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 6/2/2025 and
reported they had no additional information.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/3/2025. Chief Administrator (CA) stated she does
recall Youth A injuring his hand while on a parental visit as this
was the only time Youth A had sustained an injury, the parental
visit occurred in Flint, MI. This incident happened when Youth A
was around the age of 12 or 13. Youth’s A Former Therapist was
attacked in the vehicle by Youth A while he was being transported
back to the facility. Former Therapist was attacked after a visit
Youth A had with his mother and Former Therapist had to turn the
car around, and drive back to Youth A’s mother’s home to assist
with Youth A’s behavior. She recalls Youth’s A mother having to
assist with calming him down. Chief Administrator stated a staff
member did not break Youth’s A hand.
Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
6/3/2025. Clinical Director reported she vaguely recalls the
incident with Youth A injuring his hand. She recalled Youth A was
on a visit with his mother, Youth A attacked Former Therapist and
Youth A had banged his fist into the pavement. She could not
recall further details. Clinical Director stated that a staff member
did not break his hand.
Residential Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/3/2025. Residential Supervisor 1 stated he was not
present for the incident, however, he was the supervisor that
received the call that Youth A’s mother was restraining him as he
was trying to fight Former Therapist and he was banging his hand
into the concrete outside. He does recall that they had to send
Former Staff 2 and Former Staff 3 to Flint, MI to assist with the
situation.
Youth A was interviewed via video conference on 6/4/2025.
Youth A stated that in 2019 on a Friday, date unknown, he was on
a hall pass to visit his mother in Flint, MI. He stated he became
upset with a staff member that he does not recall due to the staff

7

Residential Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone on

He could not recall if this was something Youth A’s mother told

• Emergency Medical Policy:
• Treatment Standards and Expectations
o To provide optimal, quality care for our high-risk, special
needs children, it is essential that all personnel employed
by the Christ Child House conduct themselves in a highly
professional manner to carry out their respective duties and
responsibilities. We must understand that first we are a
treatment center, not a home and that we are also a haven
for abused children, so everything needs to be taken in the
context of that.
o Although it is impossible to delineate every detail of how we
need to perform our jobs professionally, the following
guidelines are intended to convey many of the important
parameters within which we all need to function to
effectively carry out our jobs.
o I. Responsibilities of Staff:
o All staff on duty are responsible for the proper treatment
and safety of all children.
o All staff are responsible for providing a nurturing, supportive
and treatment oriented environment for all residents. In
order to create and maintain this type of environment, staff
will work to develop strong therapeutic relationships with
the children under their care. These relationships will be
built in part by: 1) ensuring that the basic needs (e.g., food,
clothing, adequate sleep, safety and medical care) of all
residents are satisfactorily met; 2) helping and teaching the
children to solve problems rather than to bottle them up
and/or act them out;
o Staff will provide positive feedback to children for their
achievements. Similarly, staff will provide critical feedback
to residents in a constructive and respectful manner to
motivate more appropriate and positive growth-producing
behavior from them. Staff must be positive role models at
all times.
9

o To provide a therapeutic and safe environment, staff will
intervene as necessary when acting out behavior(s) occur.
All interventions will begin with the least restrictive one
possible.
o It may be necessary at times for staff to intervene with
physical management, but only to protect a child from
imminent dangers to themselves or others and always as a
last resort. At all times staff will obtain supervisory
authorization, use the least restrictive physical
management technique, and log the incident on a physical
management form during the shift worked. When staff
have been involved in the physical restraint of a child, all
staff directly involved must record the circumstances of the
intervention. The logging of such an event will include a
description of the circumstances leading up to the use of
physical restraint, a description of the intervention itself,
and a description of the problem involved during the
restraint, along with an account of its resolution and
subsequent processing with the child.
o Staff will be responsible for helping our children
appropriately present themselves by ensuring they are
groomed properly, dressed neatly and appropriately for the
weather/occasion. Staff should also ensure that the boys
do not take any inappropriate materials to school (clothing
changes, MP3’s, radios, money).
o Staff will be made aware of treatment expectations for the
boys to allow them to properly address their behaviors.
o Staff are responsible to be knowledgeable of the resident’s
de-escalation forms, which are located in the Supervisor
Office in a binder labeled Resident De-escalation Forms.
o II. Prohibitions
o Physical or corporal punishment is prohibited with our
children in any situation. In a treatment center,
consequences are to be used for misbehavior, not
punishment. Punishment is never therapeutic, logical and
natural consequences are.
o Excessive or inappropriate use of force or restraint should
never be used with our children. Any intervention must
adhere to the guidelines of the agency’s Restraint Policy.
Restraints must never be utilized in bathrooms or on
stairwells or other dangerous areas. It is the philosophy of
Christ Child House that discipline is an educational process
of establishing and teaching an orderly way of life. This will
protect and maintain the integrity of the individual, the
agency, and will be acceptable to society. Discipline is not
10

a procedure applied to an individual because his behavior
has displeased someone in authority; that is punishment.
o Appropriate methods of behavior management include but
are not limited to time-outs, loss of privileges, chores,
redirection and behavioral contracts. Behavioral
management methods should always be appropriate to the
age of the child.
o The following techniques are prohibited:
o Any form of corporal punishment or physical force
(including the use of a switch, belt, paddle, extension cord
or other objects to strike a child).
o Restricting a child’s movements by binding or tying him/her.
o Application of any substance, which would cause a child to
be burned.
o Confining a child in an area such as a closet, locked room,
box or similar cubicle.
o Withholding necessary food, rest or toilet use.
o Mental or emotional cruelty, such as humiliating, shaming,
or frightening a child this includes threatening harm or
swearing/cursing (using foul language) at them.
o Verbal abuse, threats or derogatory remarks.
o Corporal punishment inflicted in any manner, including
spanking or slapping.
o The depriving of visits or other contact with the child’s
biological family as a form of punishment.
o Any kind of purposefully inflicted physical discomfort such
as marching, standing rigidly in one spot for extended
periods, depriving the child of sleep or forcing food.
o Denial of necessary educational, medical, counseling or
social services work.
o Any form of physical, emotional or sexual abuse.
o Child handling techniques used should assist the youth in
understanding their behavior and promoting self-control,
self-esteem and independence and must be positive and
consistent based on the child’s needs and stage of
development. Discipline and child handling techniques are
recorded in the Treatment Plan and Service Agreement.
The techniques must be child specific.
o Staff may use reasonable restraint to prevent imminent
harm to self or others. Remember to exhaust all other
efforts before placing hands on.
o A child is never to be placed in seclusion. No children
should ever be sent to a room unescorted. Children are to
be supervised at all times.
11

o Staff should never allow a child to be verbally or physically
aggressive with a peer. Teach and encourage the children
to treat each other respectfully.
o Meals and snacks, including desserts should never be
withheld as a means of punishment or consequence. Food
is a right not a privilege and critically important to an child.
The only dietary restrictions are those dictated by a doctor
or agency nurse.
o Staff will not ridicule, belittle or use sarcasm with a child or
family. Staff will never even jokingly threaten to harm
children or use corporal punishment. Staff should never
communicate on a child’s level when upset or angry.
o Staff will avoid shouting or screaming at a child. Shouting
over a child is not therapeutic. Staff will never use profane
or vulgar language with a child. Staff will not utilize “street”
terminology, only professional or clinical language.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews and
documentation, there is insufficient evidence to support the
allegation that an unknown staff member broke Youth’s A wrist.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted into allegations that a youth (Youth A) was sexually assaulted by a staff member (Staff 1) and by another youth (Youth B), and that a staff member broke his wrist. The investigation, relying on interviews and record reviews, found insufficient evidence to support any of the allegations, noting that key records were purged, the accused staff member is deceased, and witness accounts contradicted the youth's claims. While the report concludes no violations were substantiated, the tragic nature of the allegations and the inability to fully corroborate or refute them due to time and record-keeping issues leaves a lingering question about the facility's historical oversight.
